title: Use React for frontend framework

technicalStory.title: Select frontend framework for new web application
technicalStory.description: We need to choose a frontend framework for building our new customer-facing web application

context.problem: We need to select a frontend framework for our new web application that will support rapid development, maintainability, and scalability
context.background: Our team is building a new customer-facing web application from scratch. The application will have complex UI requirements including real-time updates, interactive dashboards, and responsive design
constraints: Team has varying levels of frontend expertise
Must integrate with existing REST APIs
Needs to support IE11 for enterprise customers
assumptions: Team will have time for training on new framework
Performance requirements can be met by modern frameworks
Community support will remain strong for chosen framework

decisionDrivers.description: How easy is it for developers to be productive
How quickly can team members become productive

options.name: React
options.description: Facebook's component-based library for building user interfaces
pros: Flexible - can be used for small to large applications
Strong job market for React developers
cons: Just a library, not a full framework
Requires additional libraries for routing, state management

options.name: Angular
options.description: Google's full-featured framework for building web applications

options.name: Vue.js
options.description: Progressive JavaScript framework for building user interfaces

decision.rationale: React provides the best balance of community support, developer experience, and flexibility for our needs. While it requires additional libraries, this gives us more control over our architecture. The large ecosystem means we can find solutions and developers more easily.
decision.implementation: We will use Create React App for initial setup, React Router for routing, and Redux Toolkit for state management. We'll establish coding standards and component libraries early in the project.

validation.method: Build a proof of concept with each framework
successCriteria: Team can build a CRUD interface in less than 1 week
At least 80% of team feels comfortable with the choice

positive: Access to large ecosystem of components and libraries
Easy to hire experienced React developers
Flexibility to structure application as needed
negative: Need to make additional architecture decisions (state management, routing)
JSX syntax requires training for backend developers
Need to keep up with ecosystem changes
neutral: Will need to establish our own best practices
Regular dependency updates will be required

estimatedCost.development: No license costs, 2 weeks team training
estimatedCost.maintenance: 1 developer day per month for updates

notes: Consider reviewing this decision in 6 months based on team feedback and project progress. May need to add Server-Side Rendering (SSR) with Next.js if SEO becomes a requirement.
